title: Elton John's 'deep friendship' with Freddie Mercury revealed
text:
Freddie and Elton had a ‘deep friendship’ (Pictures: REX)

Elton John can count himself as one of Freddie Mercury’s most dearest friends, and spent hours at a time with the Queen singer in the days before his death 28 years ago.

Their ‘deep friendship’ is the reason why Elton, 72, kindly stepped in to make sure some of Freddie’s other close friends weren’t lonely at Christmas, which fell just a month after the rocker died in November 1991.

As two of the biggest music stars Britain had to offer, it’s no surprise that Elton and Freddie struck up a tight bond. After all, they had plenty in common.

Peter “Phoebe” Freestone, Freddie’s longtime personal assistant, has reminisced on their friendship, telling Metro.co.uk: ‘They actually became close friends.

‘They then missed seeing each other quite often because both of them, both Queen and Elton were just non-stop touring. And we were rarely in the same city at the same time.’

Advertisement

Peter worked with Freddie for 12 years and was there by the musician’s side just one day before he passed.

Sharing his fond memories, continued: ‘But every now and then it would happen and they would get together and there would just be no stopping and just talking, talking, talking, talking for hours and hours just to catch up on what has happened since the last Sunday.

Freddie, here with Peter Straker, and Elton (Picture: Getty Images)

‘Then once he got sick and he was at home a bit more, Elton would come around regularly, maybe every fortnight he would come around and he would sit and talk with Freddie particularly during that last year.’

‘[He would] just sit there talking with him, just so that Freddie knew he wasn’t alone, and that really showed the genuine, deep friendship between them.’

Elton has previously spoken of how, even in his final days, Freddie went to the effort of buying him a Christmas present.

Peter was actually there when Freddie bought the gift – a painting from Henry Scott Tuke.

Recalling the experience, Peter said: ‘During that time, it must have been the last six months, we were at one of the auction rooms and he saw a painting by one of Elton’s favorite painters, and Freddie bought it for him thinking of it as a Christmas present for Elton.

‘I mean, not knowing that he was going to die in the November and after Freddie died, I knew what this picture was for Elton and Freddie had wrapped it up in a in a pillow case.

Freddie died after a battle with AIDs in 1991 (Picture: Redferns)

‘I remember that, it wasn’t wrapped up in paper it was in a pillow case. It’s what he wanted to do.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Elton made sure to spend quality time with Freddie and was a regular visitor at the singer’s Kensington home.

‘We all knew that the end was coming. I think it was maybe a week before Elton came. He had to go to Paris to record so he gave us all his numbers to call him should anything happen,’ Peter revealed.

‘But it was within a week that Freddie died the last time he visited.

‘Press were outside the house 24 hours a day and they would question anybody who came to the front door.

‘What Elton used to do, he would drive himself in his mini and park in the mews behind Garden Lodge.’

According to Peter: ‘He would phone ahead and say exactly what time he would be there, we would let him in, he’d go and see Freddie and disappear.

‘Nobody knew that Elton was visiting except for that very last time he was driven in one of his Bentley’s to the front door and then people were asking: “What’s happening? Why are you here? What’s going on?” And he just said I’ve just come see my friend.’

Freddie died on 24 November 1991 at the age of 45 due to complications from AIDs.

Even after the singer had passed, Elton still looked out for those who were closest to the Bohemian Rhapsody legend.

Peter recalled: ‘Elton came round to the house after Freddie died and ask the three of us – because of course Jim Hutton was there Joe Fanelli and myself – and he asked what we were doing for Christmas because Elton knew Freddie always had big Christmases.

Advertisement

‘Freddie would always invite anybody. Any friends who did not have family were invited to Christmas. I remember once having to do Christmas lunch for 25 people.’

The former assistant continued: ‘After Freddie died, Elton came and he said, “What are you guys doing for Christmas?” He then said, “Look than enough of this. I will send a car on Boxing Day you will come to Windsor and you will have Christmas with us”.

‘And we took the present with us just to make sure that Freddie’s wish happened. That Elton got this picture. Elton’s spoken about it, I’ve seen him talk about it before.

‘But Freddie, even though he was within months of death would still think of his friends.’

Freddie Mercury’s Never Boring box set is available to buy now.
